title: Psalms Chapter 138 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 138 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 138 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 138.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms 138?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:1 states that it is 'A Psalm of David.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 138:1, with what will the psalmist praise the Lord?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:1 says, 'I will praise thee with my whole heart.'

questions.question: Where will the psalmist worship according to Psalms 138:2?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:2 says, 'I will worship toward thy holy temple.'

questions.question: What has God magnified above all his name according to Psalms 138:2?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:2 says, 'for thou hast magnified thy word above all thy name.'

questions.question: What did God do in the day the psalmist cried according to Psalms 138:3?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:3 says, 'In the day when I cried thou answeredst me, and strengthenedst me with strength in my soul.'

questions.question: Who shall praise the LORD when they hear the words of His mouth as stated in Psalms 138:4?
options: All the kings of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: All the kings of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:4 says, 'All the kings of the earth shall praise thee, O LORD, when they hear the words of thy mouth.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 138:5, why shall they sing in the ways of the LORD?
options: Because great is the glory of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Because great is the glory of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:5 says, 'for great is the glory of the LORD.'

questions.question: What does the LORD have respect unto according to Psalms 138:6?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:6 says, 'Though the LORD be high, yet hath he respect unto the lowly.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 138:6, how does the LORD regard the proud?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:6 says, 'but the proud he knoweth afar off.'

questions.question: What will the LORD do when the psalmist walks in the midst of trouble according to Psalms 138:7?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:7 says, 'Though I walk in the midst of trouble, thou wilt revive me.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 138:7, what will the LORD do against the wrath of the psalmist's enemies?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:7 says, 'thou shalt stretch forth thine hand against the wrath of mine enemies.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 138:8 states that the LORD will perfect what concerns the psalmist.
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:8 says, 'The LORD will perfect that which concerneth me.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 138:4 says that only the people of Israel will praise the LORD when they hear His words.
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:4 says 'All the kings of the earth shall praise thee,' not only the people of Israel.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 138:3, God strengthens the psalmist with strength in his body.
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:3 states that God strengthened the psalmist 'with strength in my soul,' not in the body.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 138:8: 'The LORD will perfect that which ______ me.'
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:8 states, 'The LORD will perfect that which concerneth me.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 138 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 138 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 138, what biblical truth would you share about God’s help in trouble?
options: God will revive and save you even in the midst of trouble
God will leave you to face trouble alone
God only helps those who are wealthy
God’s help depends on your strength
questions.correctAnswer: God will revive and save you even in the midst of trouble
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:7 says that even when walking through trouble, God revives the soul and saves by stretching out His hand. This truth encourages perseverance and trust during trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 138 teach us about humility and God’s regard for people?
options: God respects the lowly but knows the proud from afar
God only respects the proud and powerful
God ignores the lowly and humble
God treats everyone the same without regard
questions.correctAnswer: God respects the lowly but knows the proud from afar
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:6 stresses God’s special respect for the humble and lowly, contrasting this with His distance from the proud, teaching humility as a virtue.

questions.question: What practical encouragement does Psalms 138 offer about trusting God’s faithfulness in prayer?
options: God answers us and strengthens our soul when we cry out to Him
God ignores our prayers when in distress
God only answers prayers if we are perfect
God answers only some prayers selectively
questions.correctAnswer: God answers us and strengthens our soul when we cry out to Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:3 teaches that God responds to our cries and strengthens us, offering assurance to those who pray with faith and sincerity.

questions.question: How does Psalms 138 emphasize the importance of praising God with sincerity in personal devotion?
options: Praise God with your whole heart before other gods
Praise God only when others are watching
Praise God only in public gatherings
questions.correctAnswer: Praise God with your whole heart before other gods
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:1 highlights wholehearted praise before other gods, encouraging sincere and full devotion in worship.

questions.question: A believer wonders how to maintain integrity in their daily work. What principle from Psalms 138 can you share?
options: Trust God to perfect the work of your hands
Focus only on personal gain without relying on God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to perfect the work of your hands
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:8 affirms that the LORD will perfect what concerns us and not forsake the work of His hands, encouraging trust and integrity in our labor.

questions.question: What does Psalms 138 teach about God’s lovingkindness and truth in relation to His Word?
options: God’s Word is magnified above all His name because of His lovingkindness and truth
God’s Word is less important than other things
God’s Word is only for kings
questions.correctAnswer: God’s Word is magnified above all His name because of His lovingkindness and truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:2 says God has magnified His Word above all His name due to His lovingkindness and truth, emphasizing the supreme value of Scripture in Christian living.

questions.question: How does Psalms 138 encourage believers to share the Gospel with others?
options: All the kings of the earth will praise the LORD when they hear His words
Keep the Gospel a secret from others
Only preachers should share the Gospel
The Gospel is not meant for everyone
questions.correctAnswer: All the kings of the earth will praise the LORD when they hear His words
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:4 teaches that when people hear God’s words, even kings will praise Him, encouraging believers to share the Gospel boldly.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 138, God’s mercy is temporary and depends on our actions.
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:8 clearly states that God’s mercy endures forever, indicating His unchanging and everlasting compassion.

questions.question: How does Psalms 138 teach about God’s glory in our walk of faith?
options: Great is the glory of the LORD, and we shall sing in His ways
God’s glory is hidden and not to be celebrated
God’s glory depends on our success
We should not focus on God’s glory
questions.correctAnswer: Great is the glory of the LORD, and we shall sing in His ways
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:5 encourages believers to sing and rejoice in the ways of the LORD, acknowledging the greatness of His glory.

questions.question: A new Christian is learning about worship. What does Psalms 138 teach about the direction and focus of worship?
options: Worship toward God’s holy temple and praise His name
Worship only in private without mentioning God’s name
Worship without regard for God’s holiness
questions.correctAnswer: Worship toward God’s holy temple and praise His name
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:2 instructs worship directed toward God’s holy temple and praising His name because of His lovingkindness and truth, emphasizing reverence and focus in worship.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 138, God is distant and uncaring toward those who are humble.
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:6 states that though God is high, He respects the lowly, showing His care and attention toward the humble.

questions.question: How does Psalms 138 encourage believers to respond when enemies show wrath or opposition?
options: Trust that God will stretch out His hand and save you
Ignore God and rely on your own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will stretch out His hand and save you
questions.explanation: In Psalms 138:7, God promises to stretch out His hand against the wrath of enemies and save His people, encouraging faith and dependence on God’s protection.

questions.question: A family is learning about gratitude and trust in God’s plans. How does Psalms 138 speak to God’s involvement in our lives?
options: The LORD will perfect what concerns us and will not forsake His work
We are on our own without God’s help
God only helps when we ask once
God is indifferent to our daily concerns
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will perfect what concerns us and will not forsake His work
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:8 reassures believers that God perfects what concerns them and will not abandon His own works, teaching trust and gratitude for His care.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "I will praise thee with my whole _____: before the gods will I sing praise unto thee."
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:1 begins with David declaring praise with his whole heart, emphasizing sincere and wholehearted worship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 138 encourage perseverance and faith during personal trials?
options: God strengthens the soul and revives us in trouble
God abandons us in times of hardship
Only our efforts can overcome difficulties
questions.correctAnswer: God strengthens the soul and revives us in trouble
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:3 and 138:7 together emphasize God’s strengthening and reviving presence during trials, encouraging perseverance through faith.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 138 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 138.

questions.question: In Psalms 138:2, what is said to be magnified above all thy name?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:2 states, 'for thou hast magnified thy word above all thy name,' emphasizing the supreme value of God's promises and decrees.

questions.question: According to Psalms 138:3, what did God do in the day when the psalmist cried?
options: He answered and strengthened the soul
questions.correctAnswer: He answered and strengthened the soul
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:3 says, 'In the day when I cried thou answeredst me, and strengthenedst me with strength in my soul,' indicating God's personal intervention and inner strengthening.

questions.question: Which group is said to praise the LORD upon hearing the words of His mouth in Psalms 138:4?
options: All the kings of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: All the kings of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:4 declares, 'All the kings of the earth shall praise thee, O LORD, when they hear the words of thy mouth,' showing the universal recognition of God's word.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Psalms 138:6 where the LORD is described as having respect to the lowly but knowing the proud afar off?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:6 contrasts God's favor toward the humble and His distance from the proud, illustrating the moral disposition of God through literary contrast.

questions.question: In the cultural context of ancient Near Eastern kingship, what does Psalms 138:5 imply about the LORD's glory?
options: It is greater than earthly rulers' glory
It is shown through military conquest
questions.correctAnswer: It is greater than earthly rulers' glory
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:5 says, 'for great is the glory of the LORD,' which in context contrasts with earthly kings mentioned in verse 4, asserting God's supreme and universal glory.

questions.question: Which aspect of God’s character is especially highlighted in Psalms 138:8?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:8 emphasizes, 'thy mercy, O LORD, endureth for ever,' highlighting the perpetual nature of God's mercy as central to His dealings with the psalmist.

questions.question: The phrase 'thy right hand shall save me' in Psalms 138:7 is a typological reference to what common biblical theme?
questions.explanation: The 'right hand' symbolizes God's power and intervention throughout Scripture, such as in Exodus and Isaiah, emphasizing salvation and protection as seen in Psalms 138:7.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 138:1 expresses the psalmist’s intent to praise God only privately and silently.
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:1 states, 'before the gods will I sing praise unto thee,' indicating public and vocal praise, not private or silent worship.

questions.question: What is the significance of the psalmist worshiping 'toward thy holy temple' in Psalms 138:2 in the historical context of Israel?
options: It reflects the centrality of the temple as God's dwelling
It denotes syncretism with pagan worship
It indicates a personal vision of heaven
It symbolizes the end of exile
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the centrality of the temple as God's dwelling
questions.explanation: In ancient Israel, worship toward the temple was standard, as it was considered God's earthly dwelling place, showing reverence and acknowledgment of His holiness (Psalms 138:2).

questions.question: How does Psalms 138:4-5 use parallelism to reinforce the theme of universal praise?
options: By connecting kings' praise with singing in God's ways
questions.correctAnswer: By connecting kings' praise with singing in God's ways
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 5 use synonymous parallelism: kings will praise the LORD and sing in His ways, reinforcing the universal acknowledgment of God's glory.

questions.question: Which Hebrew term translated as 'lovingkindness' in Psalms 138:2 is key to understanding God's covenant faithfulness?
questions.explanation: 'Chesed' is the Hebrew word often rendered as 'lovingkindness' in Psalms 138:2, denoting steadfast love and covenant loyalty in the Old Testament.

questions.question: In Psalms 138:7, what does the promise to 'stretch forth thine hand against the wrath of mine enemies' suggest about the psalmist's relationship with God?
options: God as judge of Israel only
questions.explanation: The verse highlights God's active intervention to save and defend the psalmist from enemies, indicating a personal, protective covenant relationship.

questions.question: The structure of Psalms 138 can be seen as a chiastic pattern emphasizing which central theme?
questions.explanation: The psalm’s structure revolves around praise, God’s responses, universal recognition, and ends with assurance of mercy, forming a chiasm centered on divine faithfulness (Psalms 138).

questions.question: How does Psalms 138:6 foreshadow the New Testament teaching about humility and pride?
options: By illustrating God’s favor on the humble and distance from the proud
questions.correctAnswer: By illustrating God’s favor on the humble and distance from the proud
questions.explanation: This verse echoes teachings such as James 4:6 where 'God resists the proud but gives grace to the humble,' showing continuity in biblical ethics.

questions.question: What is the significance of the psalmist’s declaration in Psalms 138:8 that God will 'perfect that which concerneth me'?
options: It affirms God’s ongoing providential care
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms God’s ongoing providential care
questions.explanation: The verse expresses confidence that God will complete and sustain the psalmist’s affairs, highlighting divine providence and faithfulness.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 138 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 138 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 138:1, how does David intend to praise God?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:1 states that David will praise God with his whole heart, indicating full devotion in worship. This aligns with Deuteronomy 6:5, Jeremiah 29:13, Matthew 22:37, and Romans 12:1 emphasizing wholehearted devotion to God.

questions.question: What reason does Psalms 138:2 give for praising God's name?
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:2 highlights praising God's name for His lovingkindness and truth. This reflects God's covenant faithfulness seen throughout Scripture, such as in Exodus 34:6, Psalm 89:1, John 3:16, and 2 Timothy 2:13.

questions.question: What does Psalms 138:3 say God gave David in response to his cry?
questions.explanation: The verse states God answered David's cry and strengthened him with strength in his soul. Scripture affirms God's strengthening presence in trials, e.g., Isaiah 40:29, Nehemiah 8:10, Ephesians 3:16, and Philippians 4:13.

questions.question: According to Psalms 138:4, who will praise the LORD when they hear His words?
options: All the kings of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: All the kings of the earth
questions.explanation: The verse reveals that all earthly kings will praise the LORD when hearing His words, signifying the universal sovereignty of God. This universal praise theme is supported by Psalm 22:28, Psalm 72:11, Philippians 2:10, and Revelation 15:4.

questions.question: What does Psalms 138:5 say about the ways of the LORD?
options: They are full of great glory
They are hidden from the wise
questions.correctAnswer: They are full of great glory
questions.explanation: Psalms 138:5 declares that those who walk in God's ways will sing because of His great glory. God's glorious way is affirmed in Exodus 15:11, Isaiah 6:3, Romans 11:36, and Hebrews 1:3.

questions.question: How does Psalms 138:6 describe God's attitude toward the lowly and the proud?
options: He respects the lowly but knows the proud from afar
He favors the proud and ignores the lowly
questions.correctAnswer: He respects the lowly but knows the proud from afar
questions.explanation: This verse emphasizes God's grace toward the humble and His distancing from the proud. This theme is echoed in Proverbs 3:34, James 4:6, 1 Peter 5:5, and Luke 1:52.

questions.question: In Psalms 138:7, what does David say God will do when he walks through trouble?
options: Revive him and save him from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Revive him and save him from enemies
questions.explanation: David expresses confidence that God will revive him and protect him from his enemies during trials. This assurance is consistent with Psalm 46:1, Isaiah 41:10, John 10:28, and Romans 8:31.

questions.question: What does Psalms 138:8 say about the LORD's mercy?
options: It lasts only for a time
questions.explanation: The verse affirms the eternality of God's mercy, consistent with other passages like Psalm 100:5, Lamentations 3:22-23, Ephesians 2:4-5, and Hebrews 13:5.

questions.question: What does David say God has magnified above all His name in Psalms 138:2?
questions.explanation: David declares that God has magnified His word above all His name, highlighting the supreme authority and faithfulness of God's promises. This is consistent with Isaiah 55:11, John 1:1, Hebrews 4:12, and 1 Peter 1:25.

questions.question: According to Psalms 138:1, before whom does David sing praise?
questions.explanation: David says he will sing praise before the gods, indicating God's supremacy over all spiritual beings. This concept appears in Psalm 82:1, Exodus 12:12, 1 Corinthians 8:5-6, and Colossians 1:16.

questions.question: What does Psalms 138:7 say God will do with His right hand?
questions.explanation: The verse asserts that God's right hand will save David, symbolizing divine power and deliverance. This is consistent with Exodus 15:6, Psalm 118:16, Isaiah 41:10, and Romans 8:34.

questions.question: According to Psalms 138:8, what will the LORD perfect?
questions.explanation: The verse assures that God will perfect what concerns David, indicating His providential care. This aligns with Philippians 1:6, Romans 8:28, Isaiah 46:10, and Psalm 23:3.

questions.question: How does Psalms 138:6 describe God's knowledge of the proud?
questions.explanation: The verse states God knows the proud from afar, indicating His disapproval and distance from pride. This is echoed in Proverbs 16:5, James 4:6, Luke 18:14, and 1 Timothy 6:17.

questions.question: What is the main reason kings will praise the LORD according to Psalms 138:4-5?
options: Because of the words of His mouth and His great glory
Because of His wealth and riches
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the words of His mouth and His great glory
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 5 indicate kings will praise God upon hearing His words and because of His great glory. This highlights God's authoritative word and majestic presence, supported by Isaiah 55:11, Hebrews 1:3, Psalm 29:4, and Revelation 19:1.

questions.question: What does Psalms 138:7 imply about God's protection in the midst of trouble?
options: God stretches forth His hand against enemies and revives the believer
questions.correctAnswer: God stretches forth His hand against enemies and revives the believer
questions.explanation: The verse promises God's active intervention to protect and revive the believer amid adversity, consistent with Psalm 34:17, Isaiah 43:2, John 10:28-29, and 2 Timothy 4:18.
